facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 18 of 1952 filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 18 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated December 12, 1949 of Bombay High Court by Weston and Shah JJ in First Appeal No. 456 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated December 12, 1949, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay  Weston and Shah JJ.  in First Appeal No. 456 of 1949, arising out of Judg- ment and Decree dated January 24, 1949, of the Bombay City Civil Court in Civil Suit No. 106 of 1948.

facts.text: High Court judgment arose out of Judgment and Decree dated January 24, 1949 of Bombay City Civil Court in Civil Suit No. 106 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated December 12, 1949, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay  Weston and Shah JJ.  in First Appeal No. 456 of 1949, arising out of Judg- ment and Decree dated January 24, 1949, of the Bombay City Civil Court in Civil Suit No. 106 of 1948.

facts.text: High Court passed judgment and decree on December 2, 1949 reversing City Civil Court decree for absence of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal filed with the special leave of this Court. It is directed against the judgment and decree passed December 2, 1949, by a Division Bench  Weston and Shah JJ.  of the Bombay High Court reversing, the ground of absence of jurisdiction, the judgment and decree for possession passed January 24, 1949, by the Bombay City Civil Court and directing the return of the plaint for presentation to the proper Court.

facts.text: No dispute as to the facts material for the purposes of this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute as to the facts material for the purposes of this appeal.

facts.text: Around April 15, 1908, Board of Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay auctioned plots Nos. 16, 17 and 18 of new survey Nos. 8234, 8235 and 8244 situate in the Princess Street Estate containing 2235 square yards.

anchor.surface_text: or about April 15, 1908, the Board of Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay put up to auction plots Nos. 16, 17 and 18 of new survey Nos. 8234, 8235 and 8244 situate the Princess Street Estate of the Board companytaining an area of 2235 square yards for being let certain companyditions.

facts.text: Sitaram Luxman was the highest bidder and declared the tenant at annual rent per square yard at 4.5% of Rs. 29 per square yard.

anchor.surface_text: One Sitaram Luxman was the highest bidder and was declared the tenant at an annual rent per square yard to be calculated at the rate of 41/2 per cent of Rs. 29 per square yard and he signed the memorandum of agreement incorporating the companyditions upon which the auction was held and by which he agreed to be bound.

facts.text: Sitaram Luxman signed memorandum of agreement, deposited moneys per clause 3, and entered possession.

anchor.surface_text: and he signed the memorandum of agreement incorporating the companyditions upon which the auction was held and by which he agreed to be bound. He deposited the moneys in terms of clause 3 of the companyditions, and upon such payment entered into possession of the plots.

facts.text: By clause 7, Sitaram Luxman agreed to build and complete within specified time a building consisting of 5 floors costing not less than Rs. 50,000 according to approved plans.

anchor.surface_text: By clause 7 Sitaram Luxman agreed, within the time specified therein, to build and companyplete at a companyt of number less than Rs. 50,000 a building companysisting of 5 floors with suitable offices, drains etc. according to plans and specifications to be made by an approved architect and approvedby the Board

facts.text: Sitaram Luxman erected a building on the plots known as New Sitaram Building.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this agreement the said Sitaram Luxman erected those plots a building which has since companye to be known as the New Sitaram Building.

facts.text: Indentures of lease made April 19, 1916 between Trustees and Rustomji Dhunjibhoy Sethna, receiver of Sitaram Luxman's estate appointed by High Court in Suit No. 720 of 1913.

anchor.surface_text: the companypletion of the building, by an Indenture -of lease made April 19, 1916, between, the Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay and one Rustomji Dhunjibhoy Sethna the receiver of the estate of Sitaram Luxman appointed by the High Court in Suit No. 720 of 1913,

facts.text: Lease demised the land and buildings for 999 years from April 15, 1908 at specified rent.

anchor.surface_text: the Trustees, pursuant to the said agreement and in companysideration of the monies which had been expended in the erection of the buildings and of the rent and the companyenants thereinafter reserved and companytained, demised unto the lessee all that piece of land situate their Princess Street estate together with the buildings erected thereon to hold the same for 999 years from April 15, 1908, paying therefor up to January, 15, 1909, the rent of Re. I and during the remainder of the term the yearly rent of Rs. 2,916 by equal quarterly payments.

facts.text: Lease contained covenants for lessee to pay rates/taxes, not use for certain purposes without consent, keep insured, etc.

anchor.surface_text: By the said Indenture the lessee companyenanted to pay all rates and taxes, number to use or to permit to be used, without the lessors companysent, the portion of land number built upon except as open space, number to pull down, add to or alter the buildings without such companysent, to keep in repair all drains sewers etc., to repair, pave, cleanse and paint and amend all the buildings, walls etc., to permit the lessors and their employees to enter upon the premises to inspect the companyditions thereof 48 hours numberice, to use the demised premises for residential purposes or as offices and schools only and number as a public house or liquor shop or for any business or trade,

facts.text: In 1925, all properties of Trustees vested in Bombay Municipality under Bombay Act XVI of 1925.

anchor.surface_text: In 1925 all the properties of the Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay vested in the Bombay Municipality under and by virtue of Bombay Act XVI of 1925.

facts.text: By deed of assignment dated April 26, 1948, Shri Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Limited acquired the lessee's interest.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed of assignment made April 26, 1948, Shri Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Limited, a society registered under the Bombay Co-operative Societies Act, VII of 1921, the appellant before us, acquired the lessees interest in the demised premises.

facts.text: Respondent was a monthly tenant in occupation of Block No. B/2 ground floor of New Sitaram Building at monthly rent of Rs. 52-5-9.

anchor.surface_text: June 29, 1948, the appellant served a numberice the respondent before us who was a monthly tenant in occupation of Block No. B/2 the ground floor of the New Sitaram Building at a monthly rental of Rs. 52-5-9 to quit and vacate the same July 31, 1948.

facts.text: On June 29, 1948, appellant served notice to quit on respondent to vacate by July 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: June 29, 1948, the appellant served a numberice the respondent before us who was a monthly tenant in occupation of Block No. B/2 the ground floor of the New Sitaram Building at a monthly rental of Rs. 52-5-9 to quit and vacate the same July 31, 1948.

facts.text: Respondent replied that he paid rent regularly, performed tenancy terms, and claimed protection of Bombay Rents Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: By his advocates reply the respondent maintained that he had been paying the rent regularly and otherwise performing the terms of his tenancy and claimed the protection of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947  Act LVII of 1947  The respondent number having vacated the block under his occupation the expiry of the numberice to quit,

facts.text: Appellant filed summary Suit No. 106 of 1948 in City Civil Court for possession of Block B/2 and mesne profits from August 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant filed summary Suit No. 106 of 1948 against the respondent in the City Civil Court at Bombay for vacant possession of the said Block No. B/2 the ground floor of the said New Sitaram Buildings and mesne profits from August 1, 1948, until delivery of possession.

facts.text: Appellant submitted that Bombay Rents Act 1947 did not apply to the premises.

anchor.surface_text: After stating the material facts, the appellant submitted that the Bombay Act LVII of 1947 did number apply to the demised premises.

facts.text: Respondent filed written statement claiming City Civil Court had no jurisdiction under section 28 of Bombay Act, entitled to protection of Act.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed his written statement maintaining that under section 28 of the Bombay Act the CityCivil Court had numberjurisdiction to entertain the suit. He averred that he had performed and observed all the companyditions of his tenancy and was ready and willing to do so, that the New Sitaram Building had been companystructed at the expense of the appellants predecessor in title and that the premises belonged to the appellant and number to the Government or a local authority and that the respondent was entitled to the protection of the Bombay Act LVII of 1947.

facts.text: City Civil Court decreed suit in favor of appellant on issues of jurisdiction and applicability of Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned City Civil Court Judge in a well-considered and careful judgment answered the issues in favour of the appellant and decreed the suit.

facts.text: High Court reversed trial court, held Act applies, City Civil Court no jurisdiction, directed return of plaint.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reversed the decision of the trial Judge and holding that the Bombay Act LVII of 1947 did apply to the premises and companysequently that the City Civil Court, by virtue of section 28 of that Act, had numberjurisdiction to entertain the suit, directed that the plaint, be returned to the appellant for being filed in the proper Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal after High Court declined certificate.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having declined to grant leave to the appellant to appeal to this Court, the appellant applied for and obtained special leave of this Court to prefer this appeal and filed this appeal pursuant to such leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected respondent's preliminary objection on jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we think, in agreement with the High Court, that this preliminary objection is number well founded in principle or authority and should be rejected.

facts.text: Supreme Court held demised premises belong to local authority (Bombay Municipality) and Bombay Rents Act 1947 does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: In our view in the case before us the demised premises including the building belong to a local authority and are outside the operation of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Leaving out the issue as to whether the appellant was entitled to any compensation, there were 4 issues raising in effect two points, namely, 1 whether the Court had jurisdiction and 2 whether the Bombay Act LVII of 1947 applied to the premises in suit.

issues.text: whether the Bombay Act LVII of 1947 applied to the premises in suit

anchor.surface_text: Leaving out the issue as to whether the appellant was entitled to any compensation, there were 4 issues raising in effect two points, namely, 1 whether the Court had jurisdiction and 2 whether the Bombay Act LVII of 1947 applied to the premises in suit. The learned City Civil Court Judge in a well-considered and careful judgment answered the issues in favour of the appellant and decreed the suit.

issues.text: the question of the jurisdiction of the City Civil Court to entertain the suit

anchor.surface_text: The crucial point, therefore, in order to determine the question of the jurisdiction of the City Civil Court to entertain the suit, is to ascertain whether, in view of section 4 of the Act, the Act applies to the premises at all. If it does, the City Civil Court has no jurisdiction but if it does not, then it has such jurisdiction.

issues.text: whether, in view of section 4 of the Act, the Act applies to the premises at all

anchor.surface_text: is to ascertain whether, in view of section 4 of the Act, the Act applies to the premises at all. If it does, the City Civil Court has no jurisdiction but if it does not, then it has such jurisdiction. The question at once arises as to who is to decide this point in controversy.

issues.text: whether the Act applies to the demised premises

anchor.surface_text: The main controversy between the parties is as to whether the Act applies to the demised premises. The solution of that controversy depends upon a true construction of section 4 (1) of the Bombay Act LVII of 1947, Which runs as follows-

issues.text: true construction of section 4 (1) of the Bombay Act LVII of 1947

anchor.surface_text: The solution of that controversy depends upon a true construction of section 4 (1) of the Bombay Act LVII of 1947, Which runs as follows- 4. (1) This Act shall not apply to any premises belonging to the Government or a local authority or apply as against the Government to any tenancy or other like relationship created by a grant from the Government in respect of premises,taken lease or requisitioned by the Government but it shall apply in respect of premises let to the Government or a local authority.

issues.answer: exempts premises belonging to local authority even as between lessee and sub-tenant

issues.text: whether the demised premises belonged to the Trustees for the improvement of the City of Bombay and not belong to the Bombay Municipality both of which bodies are local authorities

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant Society is that the demised premises belonged to the Trustees for the improvement of the City of Bombay and not belong to the Bombay Municipality both of which bodies are local authorities and, therefore, the Act does not apply to the demised premises.

issues.text: whether the first part of section 4(1) exempts the relationship of landlord and tenant or confers immunity on the premises belonging to Government or local authority

anchor.surface_text: It will be observed that the second part of section 4 (1) quite clearly exempts any tenancy or other like relationship created by the Government but the first part makes no reference to any tenancy or other like relationship at all but exempts the premises belonging to the Government or a local authority.

holdings.text: A Civil Court has inherent power to decide the question of its own jurisdiction, although, as a result of its enquiry, it may turn out that it has no jurisdiction over the suit.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that a Civil Court has inherent power to decide the question of its own jurisdiction, although, as a result of its enquiry, it may turn out that it has numberjurisdiction

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well settled principle allowing courts to determine applicability of barring statutes like the Act to assess own jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The preliminary objection that the City Civil Court had no jurisdiction under section 28 of the Bombay Act is not well founded in principle or authority and should be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we think, in agreement with the High Court, that this preliminary objection is number well founded in principle or authority and should be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 28 invocable only if Act applies; court must first decide Act's applicability using inherent jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The first part of section 4(1) exempts premises belonging to the Government or a local authority from the operation of the Act, conferring immunity on the premises themselves rather than merely exempting landlord-tenant relationships.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion is, therefore, irresistible that the Legislature did number by the first part intend to exempt the relationship of landlord and tenant but intended to companyfer the premises belonging to Government an immunity

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual comparison of section parts shows deliberate omission of 'tenancy' language in first part unlike second; plain meaning confers immunity to premises.

holdings.text: The immunity under the first part of section 4(1) attaches to the premises and is available not only to the Government or local authority but also to lessees deriving title from them.

anchor.surface_text: the only inference that can be drawn from this circumstance is that this departure was made deliberately with a view to exempt the premises itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deliberate linguistic departure from second part; policy protects govt/local interests in development/reversion; avoids absurd subletting issues under s15.

holdings.text: The words 'belonging to' are to be understood in their ordinary signification; the demised premises including the building belong to the lessor (local authority).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease demises land and building (act of ownership); TPA s105 transfers no ownership; covenants show lessor control; agreement makes building lessor's property.

holdings.text: The demised premises including the building belong to a local authority and are outside the operation of the Bombay Rents Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: In our view in the case before us the demised premises including the building belong to a local authority and are outside the operation of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s4(1) exemption to facts: vesting in Municipality (local authority); building part of demised premises owned by lessor.

anchor.surface_text: Further, as pointed out by Romer L. J. in Clark v. Downes 1 , which case was approved by Lord Goddard C.J. in Rudler v. Franks 1  such immunity will increase the value of the right of reversion belonging to the Government or a local authority.

precedents.cited_proposition: such immunity will increase the value of the right of reversion belonging to the Government or a local authority

precedents.cited_proposition: approved Clark v. Downes; such immunity will increase the value of the right of reversion belonging to the Government or a local authority

precedents.citation: Heritable Reversionary Company v. Mullar 1 ... 1892 A.C. 598 at 021

anchor.surface_text: Said Lord Macnaghten in Heritable Reversionary Company v. Mullar 1 --  I   1892 A.C. 598 at 021, The words Property and belonging to are number technical words in the law of Scotland. They are to be understood, I think, in their ordinary signification. They are infact companyvertible terms you can hardly explain the one except by using the other. A mans property is that which is his own, that which belongs to him. What belongs to him is his pro- perty.

precedents.cited_proposition: The words Property and belonging to are not technical words in the law of Scotland. They are to be understood, I think, in their ordinary signification. They are infact convertible terms you can hardly explain the one except by using the other. A mans property is that which is his own, that which belongs to him. What belongs to him is his property.
precedents.cited_holding: Property and belonging to are convertible terms; a man's property is that which belongs to him
